description:
Aspidoscelis marmoratus, commonly known as the marbled whiptail, is a species of lizard that belongs to the family Teiidae. This species is native to the southwestern United States, primarily found in the states of Arizona, New Mexico, and Texas.

The marbled whiptail is a medium-sized lizard, typically ranging from 8 to 12 inches in total length, including the long, slender tail. Its body is covered in small, granular scales that are primarily brown or grayish in color, with distinctive patterns of lighter and darker marbling or mottling across the back and sides.

Aspidoscelis marmoratus is an active, diurnal lizard that is known for its rapid movements and ability to run quickly across the ground. It is an omnivorous species, feeding on a variety of insects, small invertebrates, and even plant material.

This lizard is an important component of the desert and arid grassland ecosystems in which it resides, playing a role in the food web as both a predator and prey species. Aspidoscelis marmoratus is generally considered a common and widespread species, but it may face threats from habitat loss and fragmentation due to human activities in its native range.
